topics.topic_html:
Physical and Chemical Properties of the Surface Water Collected from Various Sites to Measure of the Organic Carbon

Abstract :

The southern coastal area of Bangladesh is significant for its remarkable hydrogeological features and aquifer systems. Barisal University attempted to examine and evaluate the quality of its groundwater. The purpose of this study was to analyse the current state of physicochemical qualities in five different water reservoirs :

  • Kirtonkhola River
  • London Bridge Lake
  • Pond (1) in front of the VC gate
  • Pond (2) in front of the library
  • Pond 3 in front of the Girls' Dormitory

This study measured surface water pH, TDS, EC, DO, and BOD as well as water physicochemical measurements to determine the amount of water carbon in five fresh water reservoirs on and around the Barishal University campus.

Introduction

Surface water, a crucial natural resource, is essential for various human activities, including drinking, irrigation, and industrial processes. However, anthropogenic activities and natural processes can significantly impact the physicochemical properties of surface water, affecting its quality and suitability for different uses. This study aims to evaluate the physicochemical properties of surface water samples collected from five distinct sites in University of Barishal

Physicochemical parameters, such as pH, temperature, conductivity, turbidity, total dissolved solids (TDS), and dissolved oxygen (DO), provide valuable insights into the overall water quality. Deviations from established standards can indicate
pollution or environmental degradation. By analysing these parameters, this study seeks to assess the current state of the surface water bodies and identify potential sources of contamination

The findings of this research will contribute to a better understanding of the environmental conditions in the study area and inform decision-making regarding water resource management, pollution control, and public health.

Study Sites :

This study was conducted on August 18th to 23rd 2024 on the University of Barishal's five aquatic sites as seen in figure-02 & 03. The east-side parking lots were built for water to drain into the ditches that run along the backside of the campus. These ditches then drain into the duck pond located south of the parking lot. There were five stations along the drainage ditches and the pond where test samples were taken in order to determine water quality

Collections of Samples :

To gather samples, prewashed 1L plastic bottles were used. The bottles were washed again with sample water. The bottles were tightly closed before being plunged in lakes in fig-(02,03,04) and ponds to a depth of 0.5 m. Bottles were opened in the water to collect samples, then closed again. The samples were obtained from five distinct locations, with replicates of each sampling site.

Physicochemical Parameters :
  • Samples were taken to determine the elemental qualities of the lake and pond water
  • The parameters measured and analysed were pH and total dissolved solids
  • The water temperature was measured with a Centigrade thermometer
  • The colour of water was observed to have an effect on eye distinguishing
  • Secchi discs were used to record the transparency
  • After transporting the samples to the MS laboratory of the Department of Soil and Environmental Sciences at the University of Barishal, the remaining properties were analysed
  • The electric conductivity and pH of the water were measured using a Pocket multipara meter (HANNA Instruments, model DiST4, HI98304)
  • A portable dissolved oxygen meter (DO meter, Model DO30) was used to measure the water's dissolved oxygen

PH

Principle :
  • pH is a measure of acidity and alkenity of the water
  • A pH of seven is neutral , while values below 7 are acidic and above are alkaline
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that the pH of drinking water should be between 6.5 and 8.5 , this range is considered safe and acceptable for human consumption
Apparatus :
  • Beaker 100 ml
  • Glass electrode pH meter( Model: HI700663)
  • Stirring rods
  • Sample water
Procedure :
  • 10 ml sample was taken into a 100 ml Baker
  • The pH meter (Model: HI700663) was switched on and adjusted with the sample
  • The electrode was placed into the sample and read the pH value
  • Result among the group 7.9 - 7.44 - 7.44-7.21-7.85
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION of pH :

The pH of the sampling locations ranged between 7.95 and 8.15 on average. The greatest pH value was 7.90, while the minimum was 7.21. Sewage or terrestrial run-off from surrounding abodes containing carbonates and bicarbonates may be responsible for the highest pH readings in sample sites. Typically, alkaline water aids in the proliferation of phytoplankton in confined water bodies. Research has revealed that pH ranges of 7-8 are suitable for fish culture and the majority of aquatic species. The pH in most raw water sources ranges between 6.5 and 8.5 (1416). The pH of these water reservoirs imply the prospect of suitable aquaculture, and it was previously noted that this city has phytoplankton richness in its freshwater bodies.

TDS

Principle :
  • The principle behind using an EC meter to determine TDS is that the dissolved salts and minerals in water contribute to it’s electrical conductivity.
  • The conversion factor usually ranges from 0.5 to 0.7, depending on the specific ionic composition of the water
Apparatus :
  • Beaker 100 ml
  • Sample water
  • EC meter (JENCO- EC330)
Procedure :
  • 10 ml sample was taken into a 100 ml beaker
  • The EC meter (JENCO- EC330) was switched on and adjusted with the sample
  • The electrode was placed into the sample and read the TDS value
  • Result among the group : 110-95-130-75-65
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION of pH :

Total dissolved solids in aquatic environments primarily indicate the inorganic pollution load of the water system, whereas electrical conductivity measures the concentration of ions in water.The study area had the highest levels of TDS (130 mg/l) and EC (135 μS/cm) and the lowest values of TDS (65 mg/l) and EC (260 μS/cm).
As we can see from the TDS readings, all of the samples' test results were around (65-130)ppm, which is not ideal based on WHO recommendations of (150-250)ppm. Fortunately none of the samples' test results came close to the standard, hence the TDS of all the samples is extremely low. The addition of organic compounds from degraded aquatic creatures may be responsible for the total dissolved solids concentration. As TDS values vary, so may the algae diversity found in these reservoirs.

EC

Principle :
  • Measures water's ability to conduct an electric current, which is affected by the presence of dissolved salts and minerals. Units are generally micro Siemens per centimetre (µS/cm)
  • Higher EC values imply increased dissolved ion concentrations, which can be used to evaluate water quality and detect pollution levels
Apparatus :
  • Beaker 100 ml
  • Sample water
  • EC meter (JENCO- EC330)
Procedure :
  • 10 ml sample was taken into a 100 ml beaker
  • The EC meter (JENCO- EC330) was switched on and adjusted with the sample
  • The electrode was placed into the sample and read the TDS value
  • Result among the group : 220-190-260-145-135
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION of pH :

London Bridge Lake and Kirtonkhola River have low electric conductivity (EC) values of 145 μS/cm and 135 μS/cm, indicating good water quality. BU Pond -1 and BU Pond-2 had higher electric conductivity (EC) due to water pollution, but BU Pond-3 had the highest EC at 260 μS/cm, indicating the most polluted water among the sites

DO

Principle :
  • The amount of oxygen dissolved in water that is required for aquatic life is
    referred to as dissolved oxygen. The units are milligrams per litre (mg/L)
  • The reaction produces an electrical current that is proportional to the concentration of oxygen in the water
Apparatus :
  • Beaker 100 ml
  • Sample water
  • DO meter (Model HQ30D)
Procedure :
  • 10 ml sample was taken into a 100 ml beaker
  • The DO meter (Model: HQ30D) was switched on and adjusted with the sample
  • The electrode was placed into the sample and read the DO value.
  • Result among the group : 7.81-6.81-6.47-7.96-8.74
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION of pH :

DO readings represent the physical and biological processes that occur in the water. It also reveals the level of contamination in water bodies. The lowest DO level was measured (6.47 mg/l) for all sites.

WHO recommends measuring :
  • DO levels in water for irrigation (4.5-8 ppm)
  • DO levels in fisheries (5 ppm or below)
  • DO levels in drinking (6 ppm)

So, based on our sample collection, all of our DO levels were 6.47 ppm, which is close to the drinking water guideline.As a result, the pond is not also ideal for fish culture. So Professor recommended that before approaching any fish or other aquatic organisms in this pond, it is necessary to first maintain the standard DO level

BOD

Principle :
  • A measure of the quantity of oxygen needed to breakdown organic materials in water. The units are milligrams per litre (mg/L)
  • Monitoring BOD levels contributes to the protection of aquatic ecosystems and the prevention of pollution-related harm
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION of pH :

In wastewater treatment plants, BOD is a key measure of treatment efficiency. The purpose is to reduce the BOD levels to acceptable limits before dumping treated effluent into receiving waterways.
After examining all the samples for 5 days at 20°C, the parameters (BOD, TDS, pH, EC, and DO) were determined. If we look at the BOD measurements, we can see that all of the groups had BOD levels between 2 and 3, and we know from the WHO standard chart that BOD (1-2) ppm is extremely good and (3-5) ppm is somewhat clean.
BOD levels range between 2.10 and 3.60 mg/L.BOD indicates how much oxygen bacteria will require while digesting organic materials in water. Higher BOD levels, as seen in the Kirtonkhola River, indicate higher amounts of organic pollution.

Definition
  • Chemical Bond : A chemical bond is defined as a force that acts between two or more atoms to hold them together as a stable molecule

  1. Ionic Bond: A chemical bond formed through the electrostatic attraction between positively and negatively charged ions.

    Ionic or Electrovalent compound:A compound containing ionic bond referted to ionic compound

  2. Covalent Bond: A chemical bond where two atoms share one or more pairs of electrons.(GN.Lewis)

  3. Coordinate Covalent Bond: A covalent bond where both shared electrons come from the same atom.

  4. Polar Bond: A covalent bond with unequal sharing of electrons due to differences in electronegativity between atoms and bounded atom acquire a partial and positive and negative charge,is called a polar covalent bond

    Non-Polar Bond: A non-polar covalent bond is a chemical bond where electrons are shared equally between two identical atoms or atoms with similar electronegativities.

  5. Hydrogen Bond: A weak bond between a hydrogen atom covalently bonded to an electronegative atom and another electronegative atom.

Type of chemical bond :

  • Covalent bond
  • Coordinate covalent bond

Lecture 3 (sorces of alkanes)

  • A hydrocarbon is a compound composed only of carbon and hydrogen
  • Saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes and cycloalkanes) contain only C-C single bonds
  • Alkanes have the general formula CnH2n+2

The three major sources of alkanes throughout the world are the fossil fuels. The fossil fuels are natural gas, petroleum, and coal.

Natural Gas

Natural Gas consists of approximately

  • 90%–95% methane
  • 5%–10% ethane
  • and a mixture of other relatively low-boiling alkanes, chiefly propane, butane, and 2-methylpropane

Cracking

Cracking is a process whereby a saturated hydrocarbon is converted into an unsaturated hydrocarbon plus H2

CH3CH3(800-900)∘→CH2=CH2+H2

In this example saturated hydrocarbon methane converted into unsaturated hydrocarbon ethane or ethylene

Petroleum

Petroleum is a thick, viscous, liquid mixture of thousands of compounds, most of them hydrocarbons, formed from the decomposition of marine plants and animals

Important of Petroleum

Petroleum and petroleum-derived products fuel automobiles, aircraft, and trains. They provide most of the greases and lubricants required for the machinery of our highly industrialized society.
Furthermore, petroleum, along with natural gas, provides nearly 90% of the organic raw materials for the synthesis and manufacture of synthetic fibers, plastics, detergents, drugs, dyes, and a multitude of other products.

Physical Properties of Alkanes and Cycloalkanes

Alkanes are nonpolar compounds, and the only forces of attraction between their molecules are dispersion forces, which are weak electrostatic interactions between temporary induced dipoles of adjacent atoms or molecules

Because interactions between alkane molecules consist only of these very weak dispersion forces, boiling points of alkanes are lower than those of almost any other type of compound of the same molecular weight. As the number of atoms and the molecular weight of alkanes increase, there is more opportunity for dispersion forces between their molecules and boiling points increase.

Low-molecular-weight alkanes are gases at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. Higher molecular weight alkanes are liquids. Very high molecular weight alkanes are solids. Among a set of alkane constitutional isomers, the least branched isomer generally has the highest boiling point; the most branched isomer generally has the lowest boiling point.

Reaction of Alkanes

Alkanes and cycloalkanes are quite unreactive toward most reagents, a behavior consistent with the fact that they are nonpolar compounds and contain only strong sigma bonds. Under certain conditions, however, alkanes and cycloalkanes do react with O2 and with the halogens Cl2 and Br2

The oxidation of alkanes by 02 to give carbon dioxide and water is by far their most economically important reaction. Oxidation of saturated hydrocarbons is the basis for their use as energy sources for heat [natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), and fuel oil] and power (gasoline, diesel fuel, and aviation fuel). Following are balanced equations for the complete oxidation of methane (the major compo-nent of natural gas) and propane (the major component of LPG).

    CH4+2O2→CO2+2H2OΔH∘=-890kj
  • Propane
    CH3CH2CH3+5O2→3CO2+4H20ΔH=-2220kj

An unsaturated hydrocarbon contains one or more carbon-carbon double or triple bonds. The term "unsaturation" indicates that there are fewer hydrogens bonded to carbon than in an alkane, Cn112n+2. The three most important classes of unsaturated hydrocarbons are alkenes, alkynes, and arenes. Alkenes contain a carbon-carbon double bond and, with one double bond and no rings, have the general formula CnH2n. Alkynes contain a carbon-carbon triple bond and, with one triple bond and no rings, have the general formula CnH2n-2. The simplest alkene is ethylene, and the simplest alkyne is acetylene.

Cis–trans isomerism in Alkene

Because of restricted rotation about a carbon-carbon double bond, any alkene in which each carbon of the double bond has two different groups bonded to it shows cis-trans isomerism. For example, 2-butene has two stereoisomers. In cis-2-butene, the two methyl groups are on one side of the double bond and the two hydrogens are on the other side. In trans-2-butene, the two methyl groups are on opposite sides of the double bond. These two compounds cannot be converted into one another at room temperature because of the restricted rotation about the double bond; they are different compounds (diastereomers), with different physical and chemical properties.

Buffer Solution

Definition:

A buffer solution is a solution that resists significant changes in pH when small amounts of acid or base are added. It typically contains a weak acid and its conjugate base or a weak base and its conjugate acid.

Types of Buffer Solutions:

  1. Acidic Buffer: A weak acid together with a salt of the same acid with a strong base . (CH3COOH + CH3COONa)
  2. Basic Buffer: A weak base and its salt with a strong acid (NH4OH + NH4Cl)

Example:

  1. Acidic Buffer: A mixture of acetic acid (CH₃COOH) and sodium acetate (CH₃COONa) in water.

    Acidic Buffer = CH3COOH + CH3COONa (SL1)

    CH3COOH→CH3COO-+H+
    CH3COONa→CH3COO-+Na+
    addition of HCl (acid)
    		addition of NaOH (base)
    HCl→H++Cl-
    NaOH→Na++OH-

    The new H+ should decrease the PH of the solution but the new H+ react with CH3COO- thus the PH remain same
    H++CH3COO_→CH3COOH
    		the new OH- ion should increase the PH of the solution but the new ion react with H+ and create H2O ,thus the PH remain same
    OH-+H+→H2O

    as the H+ react with new OH- so the PH of solution should decrease as the H+ decreases,but the CH3COOH produce new H+ to keep the equilibrium

    CH3COOH→CH3COO-+H+

    Upon the addition of HCl, the increase of H+ ions is counteracted by association with the excess of acetate ions to form unionized CH3COOH. Thus the added H+ ions are neutralized and the pH of the buffer solution remains virtually unchanged.When NaOH is added to the buffer solution, the additional OH– ions combine with H+ ions of the buffer to form water molecules. As a result the equilibrium (1) shifts to the right to produce more and more H+ ions till practically all the excess OH– ions are neutralized and the original buffer pH restored

    • Acetic acid dissociates partially, while sodium acetate fully dissociates into acetate ions (CH₃COO⁻).
    • When H⁺ ions are added, they react with acetate ions to form more acetic acid, minimizing pH change.

  2. Basic Buffer: A mixture of ammonia (NH₃) and ammonium chloride (NH₄Cl) in water.

    • Ammonia accepts H⁺ ions, forming NH₄⁺, and NH₄Cl provides NH₄⁺ ions.
    • When OH⁻ ions are added, NH₄⁺ reacts with them, reducing the pH change.

Explanation:

  • How it works: Buffers work by neutralizing small amounts of added acids (H⁺ ions) or bases (OH⁻ ions). The weak acid in the buffer reacts with added base, and the conjugate base reacts with added acid, maintaining the overall pH of the solution.

  • Application: Buffer solutions are used in biological systems, chemical reactions, and industrial processes where maintaining a stable pH is crucial, such as in blood, enzyme reactions, and pharmaceuticals.

Acid-Base Indicator:

An acid-base indicator is a substance that changes color depending on the pH of the solution it is added to. These indicators help to visually determine whether a solution is acidic, basic, or neutral by changing color at a specific pH range.

Phenolphthalein:

  • Definition: Phenolphthalein is a common acid-base indicator used in titrations, particularly between strong acids and strong bases.
  • Color Change:
    • In acidic solutions (pH < 8.2), phenolphthalein is colorless.
    • In basic solutions (pH > 8.2), it turns pink or magenta.
  • pH Range: Phenolphthalein changes color between pH 8.2 and 10.

Example:

  • When phenolphthalein is added to a solution of sodium hydroxide (NaOH), it turns pink because the solution is basic.

Methyl Orange:

  • Definition: Methyl orange is another acid-base indicator used primarily for titrations involving weak bases and strong acids.
  • Color Change:
    • In acidic solutions (pH < 3.1), methyl orange turns red.
    • In neutral to slightly basic solutions (pH > 4.4), it turns yellow.
  • pH Range: Methyl orange changes color between pH 3.1 and 4.4.

Example:

  • When methyl orange is added to hydrochloric acid (HCl), it turns red due to the acidic nature of the solution.

Comparison:

Indicator Acidic Color Basic Color pH Range
Phenolphthalein Colorless Pink 8.2 - 10
Methyl Orange Red Yellow 3.1 - 4.4

Phenolphthalein is preferred for strong acid-strong base titrations, while methyl orange is useful for strong acid-weak base titrations.

Hess's Law:

Hess's Law : If a chemical change can be made to take place in two or more different ways whether in one step or two or more steps, the amount of total heat change is same no matter by which method the change is brought about.

Key Idea:

  • The total enthalpy change is independent of the steps of the reaction and depends only on the initial and final states.
  • The law also follows as a mere consequence of the first law of thermodynamics
  • Hess's law has been tested experimentally and shown to be true

Example:

Consider the formation of carbon dioxide (CO₂) from carbon (C) and oxygen (O₂).

Direct Reaction:

  • Enthalpy change (ΔH) = -393.5 kJ/mol
    C(s)+O2(g)→CO2(g)

Stepwise Reaction:

  1. Formation of Carbon Monoxide (CO):

    • Enthalpy change (ΔH₁) = -110.5 kJ/mol
      C(s)+12O2(g)→CO(g)ΔH₁=-110.5

  2. Oxidation of Carbon Monoxide to Carbon Dioxide:

    • Enthalpy change (ΔH₂) = -283.0 kJ/mol
      CO(g)+12O2(g)→CO₂(g)ΔH₂=-283.0

Total Enthalpy Change:

Using Hess's Law, the total enthalpy change is: [ ΔH = ΔH₁ + ΔH₂ ] [ ΔH = -110.5 + (-283.0)= -393.5 KJ/mol

Thus, whether carbon reacts with oxygen directly or in steps, the total enthalpy change remains the same: -393.5 kJ/mol.

Application:

Hess's Law is useful for calculating enthalpy changes of reactions that are difficult to measure directly by breaking them into simpler, measurable reactions.

ThermoChemistry

Thermochemistry is the branch of physical chemistry which deals with the thermal or heat changes caused by chemical reactions.

Every substance has a definite amount of energy known as the intrinsic energy or internal energy, E.

Its exact value E cannot be determined but the change in internal energy ΔE , can be accurately measured experimentally.

Exothermic and Endotharmic Reactions
  • When the internal energy of reactants (Er) is greater than the internal energy of the products (Ep),such a reaction is called exothermic reaction
    ΔE=Ep-Er
  • When the internal energy of products (Ep) is greater than the internal energy of the reactants (Er),in this case the heat is absorbed from surrounding,such a reaction is called endothermic reaction
  • The amount of heat released or absorbed in a chemical reaction is termed the heat of reaction
  • The enthalpy of a system is defined as the sum of the internal energy and the product of its pressure and volume
    H=E+PV

    where E is the internal energy, P is the pressure and V is the volume of the system.

    It is also called Heat content

    Just like internal energy, enthalpy is also a function of the state and it is not possible to measure its absolute value. However a change in enthalpy ( DetlaH ) accompanying a process can be measured accurately and is given by the expression

    ΔH=Hp-Hr

    Thus if ΔV be the change in volume in case of a reaction at constant temperature and pressure, the thermal effect observed will be the sum of the change in internal energy ( ΔE ) and the work done in expansion or contraction

    ΔH=ΔE+P⋅ΔV

  • Let us consider a general reaction at constant pressure
    A+B→C+D

    If H_A , H_B , H_C and H_D be the enthalpies of A, B, C and D respectively, the heat of reaction at constant pressure viz., DeltaH is equal to the difference in enthalpies of the products and the reactants

    ΔH=Hp-Hr
    ΔH=(HC+HD)-(HA+HB)

    The value of DeltaH may be either zero, negative or positive

    • ΔH is zero, the enthalpies of the products and reactants being the same,the heat is evolved or absorbed
    • In case ΔH is negative, the sum of enthalpies of the products is less than that of the reactants the difference in enthalpy is given out in the form of heat

    Feature Exothermic Reactions Endothermic Reactions
    Definition Reactions that release energy (usually as heat) to the surroundings. Reactions that absorb energy (usually as heat) from the surroundings.
    Energy Change ΔH is negative (ΔH < 0).Energy released
    		 ΔH is positive (ΔH > 0).Energy absorbed
    Temperature Effect Increases the temperature of the surroundings. Decreases the temperature of the surroundings.
    Examples Combustion of fuels (e.g., burning wood, gasoline). Photosynthesis in plants.
    Reaction Profile Products have lower energy than reactants. Products have higher energy than reactants.
    Energy Diagram Reactants → Products + Energy (Heat) Reactants + Energy (Heat) → Products

    Exothermic Reaction:

    C(s)+O2(g)→CO2(g);ΔH=-393.5

    Endothermic Reaction:

    CO2(g)+H2O(l)→H2CO3(aq);ΔH=+13.1

Heat of Transition

The change in enthalpy which occurs when one mole of an element changes from one allotropic form to another

For example, the transition of diamond into amorphous carbon may be represented as

Cdiamond→CamorphousΔH=+3.3kcal

Pwhite→PredΔH=-1.028kcal
Heat of Sublimation

The heat change (or enthalpy change) when one mole of a solid is directly converted into the gaseous state at a temperature below its melting point

For example, the heat of sublimation of iodine is 14.92 kcal mol-l. It can be represented as

I2(s)→I2(g)ΔH=+14.92kcal

Heat of Vapourisation

The heat change (or enthalpy change) when one mole of liquid is converted into vapour or gaseous state at its boiling point.

For example , when one mole of water is converted into steam at 100C or 373 K, the heat absorbed is 9.71 kcal which is the heat of vaporisation of water. The change can be represented as

H2O(l)→H2O(g)ΔH=+9.71kcal

The heats of vaporisation of ethyl alcohol ( C2H5OH ) and benzene ( C6H6 ) are 7.29 kcal mol-l and 7.36 kcal mol-l respectively. The values of heats of vaporisation can also be used for the comparison of the magnitude of intermolecular forces of attraction in liquids.

Heat of Fusion

The heat change (or enthalpy change) when one mole of a solid substance is converted into the liquid state at its melting point.

As an example, we can take the melting of one mole of ice at its melting point, OC or 273 K. The process can be represented as

H2O(s)→H2O(l)ΔH=+1.43kcal

From the values of fusion of various substances we can compare their magnitudes of intermolecular forces. Greater the heat of fusion of a substance higher the magnitude of intermolecular forces.

Heat of Neutralization

The change in heat content (enthalpy) of the system when one gram equivalent of an acid is neutralised by one gram equivalent of a base or vice versa in dilute solution.

The following may be considered as typical examples of the heat of neutralisation.

HNO3+NaOH→NaNO3+H2O(l)ΔH=-13.69kcal
HCl+NaOH→NaCl+H2OΔH=-13.68kcal

It may be concluded from the above data that the heat of neutralisation of a strong acid and strong base is —13.7 kcal, no matter which acid or base is employed. ftis regularity has been explained satisfactorily with the help of the theory of ionisation. If HA and BOH represent any strong acid and any strong base respectively and equivalent amounts of these in dilute solution be mixed, we have

H++A-+B++OH-→A-+B++H2OΔH=-13.7kcal

Disregarding the ions which are present on both sides of the equation, we get

H++OH-→H2OΔH=-13.7kcal

Thus the heat of neutralisation of an acid and a base is merely the heat of formation of water from hydrogen and hydroxyl ions.

Heat of Combustion

The change in enthalpy of a system when one mole of the substance is completely burnt in excess of air or oxygen.

For Example :

CH4+2O2→CO2+2H2OΔHc=-21.0kcal

Now Consider the Chemical Equation :

C+O2→CO2ΔHc=-94.3kcal
C+12O2→COΔHc=-26.0kcal

It may be noted that — 94.3 kcal and not — 26.0 kcal is the heat of combustion of carbon as the combustion is complete only in the first reaction. In the second case, oxidation has converted carbon to carbon monoxide and is by no means complete as carbon monoxide can be further oxidised to carbon dioxide

It should be noted clearly that the heat of combustion of a substance (Hc) is always negative. Heat energy is evolved during the process of combustion i.e.,Hc = -ve.

Standard Heat of Formation

The change in enthalpy that takes place when one mole of a compound is formed from its elements, all substances being in their standard states (298 K and 1 atm pressure)

By convention the standard heat of formation of all elements is assumed to be zero.

Heat of Formation

The change in enthalpy that takes place when one mole of the compound is formed from its elements.

It is denoted by DeltaH_f.For Example

H2+Cl2→2HClΔH=-44.0kcal

It may be noted in this case that 44.0 kcal is not the heat of formation of hydrogen chloride because this amount of heat is evolved when two moles of hydrogen chloride are formed. The heat of formation of hydrogen chloride, therefore, would be — 44.0/2 = 22.0 kcal and the equation can be written as

12H2+12Cl2→HClΔHf=-22.0kcal

Equilibrium Constant

Any general reaction can be written like this :

aA + bB  🔁  cC + dD

here a,b,c,d are numerical quotients of the substance A,B,C,D resprectively  .The equilibrium contant expression is :

Kc=[C]c[D]d[A]a[B]b

🔵The product of the equilibrium concentrations of the products divided by the product of the equilibrium concentrations of the reactants, with each concentration term raised to a power equal to the coefficient of the substance in the balanced equation

Here, A BCD represent the molar concentrations of the respective species, and a,b,c,d are the stoichiometric coefficients.

Equilibrium Constant for pressure
Relation between Kc and Kp

let consider this general reacton where

aA + bB  🔁  cC + dD

where all reactant and products are gases.We can write the equilibrium constant expression in terms of partial pressure as

Kp=(PC)c(PD)d(PA)a(PB)b

Assuming that all these gases contituting the equilibrium mixture obey the ideal gas equation,the partial pressure of a gas is :

PV=nRT
P=(nV)RT

where (n/V) is the molar concentration.Thus the partial pressures of individual gases A,B,C,D are :

PA=[A]Rt,PB=[B]RT,PC=[C]RT,PD=[D]RT

Substituing these values in equation , we have

Kp=(PC)c(PD)d(PA)a(PB)b
Kp=[C]c(RT)c[D]d(RT)d[A]a(RT)a[B]b(RT)b
Kp=[C]c[D]d[A]a[B]b(RT)c+d(RT)a+b
Kp=Kc×(RT)(c+d)-(a+b)
Kp=Kc×(RT)Δn

now Δn is the difference in the sums of the coefficients for the gaseous products and reactant

if Δn = 0 then Kp = Kc

LE CHATELIER'S PRINCIPLE

In 1884, the French Chemist Henry Le Chatelier proposed a general principle which applies to all systems in equilibrium. This important principle called the Le Chatelier's principle

If a change in concentration, pressure or temperature is caused to a chemical reaction in equilibrium, the equilibrium will shift to the right or the left so as to minimise the change

Effect of Change in Concentration (Le Chatelier's Principle)

When the concentration of a reactant or product is changed in a system at equilibrium, the equilibrium will shift to counteract the change:

  • Increasing the concentration of a reactant shifts the equilibrium toward the products (right) to consume the excess reactant.
  • Decreasing the concentration of a reactant shifts the equilibrium toward the reactants (left) to produce more of the reactant.
  • Increasing the concentration of a product shifts the equilibrium toward the reactants (left) to reduce the excess product.
  • Decreasing the concentration of a product shifts the equilibrium toward the products (right) to produce more of the product.

For the reaction:

2NO2(g)⇔N2O4(g)

  1. Increase in ( NO2 ) concentration:
    The equilibrium shifts to the right, forming more ( N2O4 ).

  2. Decrease in ( NO2 ) concentration:
    The equilibrium shifts to the left, favoring the decomposition of ( N2O4 ) to produce more ( NO2 ).

  3. Increase in ( N2O4 ) concentration:
    The equilibrium shifts to the left, increasing the production of ( NO2 ).

  4. Decrease in ( N2O4 ) concentration:
    The equilibrium shifts to the right to produce more ( N2O4 ).



Effect of Change in Pressure (Le Chatelier's Principle)


When the pressure of a system at equilibrium is changed (by changing the volume), the equilibrium will shift to minimize the effect, but this only applies to reactions involving gases.


    

  • Increasing pressure shifts the equilibrium toward the side with fewer moles of gas, reducing the overall pressure.
    • 

  • Decreasing pressure shifts the equilibrium toward the side with more moles of gas, increasing the pressure.

Molecularity of a reaction
Chemical reactions may be classed into two types :
     
  • Elementary Reactions : An elementary reaction is a simple reaction which occurs in a single step
    •  
  • Complex Reactions : A complex reaction is that which occurs in two or more steps
The molecularity of a reaction refers to the number of molecules or entities involved in the elementary step of a chemical reaction. It is a concept used in kinetics to describe the number of reactant molecules that collide to form products in a single reaction event. Molecularity is only applicable to elementary reactions, which occur in a single step.


Here are the different types of molecularity:


    

  1. 

    Unimolecular Reaction: Involves a single reactant molecule. Example:
[ A ➡️ B + C ]
    

    2. 

  2. 

    Bimolecular Reaction: Involves two reactant molecules. This can be two molecules of the same species or two different species. Examples:  A + B ➡️ C 
    

    3. 

  3. 

    Termolecular Reaction: Involves three reactant molecules. This is less common due to the low probability of three molecules colliding simultaneously. Example:
[ A + B + C ➡️ D ]
    

    4. 



The molecularity is always an integer and provides insight into the reaction mechanism and how reactants interact to form products.

During Salah (Islamic prayer), there are various duas (supplications) that can be recited at different points. Here are some key ones:

1. Opening Dua (Dua al-Istiftah):

This is recited after the opening Takbir (Allahu Akbar).

  • Subhanak Allahumma wa bihamdika, wa tabaarakasmuka, wa ta’ala jadduka, wa laa ilaha ghayruka.
  • Translation: "Glory is to You, O Allah, and praise is to You; blessed is Your Name, and exalted is Your Majesty; there is no deity worthy of worship but You."

2. Dua in Ruku (Bowing):

  • Subhana Rabbiyal 'Azeem.
  • Translation: "Glory is to my Lord, the Most Great."

3. Dua in Sujood (Prostration):

  • Subhana Rabbiyal A'la.
  • Translation: "Glory is to my Lord, the Most High."

4. Dua between Sujood (Sitting between Prostrations):

  • Rabbighfir li warhamni wahdini wajburni warfa’ni wa ‘aafini warzuqni.
  • Translation: "O my Lord, forgive me, have mercy on me, guide me, strengthen me, raise me, pardon me, and provide for me."

5. Dua in Tashahhud (After the Salutation):

  • At-Tahiyyatu Lillahi was-Salawatu wat-Tayyibatu. As-Salamu 'Alaika ayyuhan-Nabiyyu wa Rahmatullahi wa Barakatuh. As-Salamu 'Alayna wa 'ala 'Ibadillahis-Saliheen. Ash-hadu alla ilaha illallah wa ash-hadu anna Muhammadan 'abduhu wa rasuluh.
  • Translation: "All greetings of humility are for Allah, and all prayers and goodness. Peace be upon you, O Prophet, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings. Peace be upon us and on the righteous servants of Allah. I bear witness that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger."

6. Dua after the final Tashahhud (before ending the prayer):

  • Allahumma inni a'udhu bika min 'adhabi jahannam wa min 'adhabi al-qabr wa min fitnati al-mahya wal-mamat wa min sharri fitnati al-masihid-dajjal.
  • Translation: "O Allah, I seek refuge in You from the punishment of Hellfire, and from the punishment of the grave, and from the trials of life and death, and from the evil of the trial of the False Messiah."

7. Dua after Salah:

After concluding the Salah with the Tasleem (saying "As-Salamu Alaikum"), you can recite:

  • Astaghfirullah (three times).
  • Allahumma antas-salamu wa minkas-salamu tabarakta ya dhal-jalali wal-ikram.
  • Translation: "O Allah, You are Peace, and from You is peace. Blessed are You, O Possessor of Majesty and Honor."

These are the main supplications, but you can also include personal prayers in your own language, asking Allah for whatever you need or desire after the obligatory prayers.

৪/সেটেলমেন্ট অফিস।

➤ইউনিয়ন ভূমি অফিস বা তহশিল অফিস। ইউনিয়ন ভূমি অফিসে যদিও খতিয়ান বা পর্চার বালাম বহি থাকে কিন্তু আপনি এই অফিসে হতে খতিয়ানের কপি নিতে পারবেন না। ইউনিয়ন ভূমি অফিস হতে শুধু খসরা খতিয়ান নিতে পারবেন যেটা আইনত কোন মূল্য নেই তারপরেও এই অফিসটি গুরুত্বপূর্ণ কারণ আপনার জমির খতিয়ান নাম্বার জানা না থাকলে এই অফিস থেকে জেনে নিতে পারবেন এছাড়া জমির খাজনা বা ভূমি উন্নয়ন কর এই অফিসে দিতে হয়।

➤উপজেলা ভূমি অফিস
যদিও উপজেলা ভূমি অফিসের মূল কাজ নামজারী বা খারিজ বা মিউটেশন করা তবে খসরা খতিয়ান তুলতে পারবেন। এই অফিস হতেও খতিয়ানের সার্টিফাইড পর্চা বা কোর্ট পর্চা তুলতে পারবেন না।

➤জেলা ডিসি অফিস
এই অফিস হতে পর্চা বা খতিয়ানের সার্টিফাইড কপি সংরক্ষণ করতে পারবেন। এই অফিসের খতিয়ান এর গুরুত্ব সর্বাধিক। সব জায়গায় এই অফিসের খতিয়ান এর গুরুত্ব রয়েছে।

➤সেটেলমেন্ট অফিস
শুধুমাত্র নতুন রেকর্ড বা জরিপের পর্চা / খতিয়ান এই অফিস হতে সংগ্রহ করা যাবে।
পাশাপাশি নতুন রেকর্ড এর ম্যাপ ও সংগ্রহ করা যায়।
❖প্রশ্নঃ খতিয়ান তুলতে কত টাকা লাগবে.?
উত্তরঃ সি এস, এস এ, আর এস, এর জন্য কত টাকা দিতে হবে তা নির্ভর করে ঐ স্থানের সিন্ডিকেটের উপর। তবে সিটি জরিপের জন্য 100 টাকা খরচ হবে।
➥দ্বিতীয়ত, আপনার জমির দলিল বা বায়া দলিল কোথায় পাবেন?
দলিল বা দলিল এর সার্টিফাইড কপি বা নকল মূলত দুটি অফিস হতে সংগ্রহ করা যায়, তা হলো।
১/উপজেলা সাব-রেজিস্ট্রি অফিস।
২/জেলা রেজিস্ট্রি বা সদর রেকর্ড রুম অফিস।

➤উপজেলা সাব-রেজিস্ট্রি অফিস
যেখানে নতুন দলিল রেজিস্ট্রেশন করা হয় এই অফিস হতে নতুন দলিলের নকল ও মূল দলিল পাওয়া যায়। কিন্তু পুরাতন দলিল বা বায়া দলিল এই অফিসে পাওয়া যায় না।

➤জেলা রেজিস্ট্রি অফিস বা সদর রেকর্ড রুম।
এই অফিসে নতুন বা পুরাতন দলিলের সার্টিফাইড কপি বা নকল পাওয়া যায়। 
❖ প্রশ্নঃ দলিল তুলতে কত টাকা খরচ হয়.?
উত্তরঃ সরকারি খরচ যদিও সামান্য কিন্তু নকলের খরচ নির্ভর করে ঐ স্থানের সিন্ডিকেটের উপর।
➥ আপনার জমির মৌজা ম্যাপ বা নকশা কোথায় পাবেন?
সাধারণত ম্যাপ বা নকশা দুইটি অফিসে পাবেন, তা হলো
১/জেলা ডিসি অফিস
২/ভূমি রেকর্ড ও জরিপ অধিদপ্তর ( DLR) অফিস, ঢাকা।

➤জেলা ডিসি অফিস:
এই অফিস হতে সিএস, এসএ, আরএস, বিএস যেকোনো মৌজা ম্যাপ সংগ্রহ করা যাবে।
সংগ্রহ করতে যা লাগবে আবেদন ফরম + 20 টাকার কোর্ট ফি এবং 500 টাকা নগদ জমা বাবদ বা ডি.সি.আর বাবদ। অর্থাৎ 530 টাকায় মৌজা ম্যাপ তুলতে পারবেন।

➤ভূমি রেকর্ড ও জরিপ অধিদপ্তর, (তেজগাঁও সাতরাস্তার মোড়), ঢাকা।
সারা বাংলাদেশের যে কোনো মৌজা ম্যাপ সিএস, এসএ, আরএস, বিএস, জেলা ম্যাপ, বাংলাদেশ ম্যাপ উক্ত অফিস হতে তুলতে পারবেন।
এই অফিসের ম্যাপের গ্রহণযোগ্যতা ও অনেক বেশি। সারা বাংলাদেশের যে কোন ম্যাপ এই অফিসে পাওয়া যায়। ম্যাপ তুলতে খরচ আবেদন ফরম + কোর্ট ফি + ডি.সি.আর মোট= ৫৫০/= টাকা মাত্র।
সকল সমস্যার জন্য নিচের সাইটটিতে সমাধান রয়েছে অথবা নাম্বার দেওয়া আছে কল করতে পারেন।
